ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to find my voice through this class. Coming in, I was hoping to develop my own style by learning how the greats did it and that's what I learned. I learned to make my writing more concise, personal, and effective.
Sharpened writing skills both in terms of craft and in terms of intent.
My essay writing and overall creative nonfiction writing skills definitely improved!
I learned how to better write non-fiction essays and learned how to write essays rather than papers.
Analyzing and reading essays and understanding how to frame an argument and point of view on a topic.
This course helped me to write more clear, concise, and detailed pieces. I learned a lot about style devices used by successful essayists as well as how to frame a topic for an essay.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class excelled at providing resources for you to use to improve your writing. The instructors give so many author examples and much needed feedback on your writing to help you develop as a writer.

The strengths of this course are largely in the essay assignments themselvesby writing in five styles, you get a handle on many types of writing, and receive feedback on every draft. The readings and discussions are also generally good, though some of the discussions can tend to ramble. Overall, a very strong course.
Professor Gellman is an incredible resource in this course - she is able to lead interesting insights from class discussion by guiding us to think more deeply about decisions made by authors.

I loved how this course was tailored to improve writing and I really saw my writing improved especially with personalized feedback and interesting readings. I do however feel that it would be helpful to understand how grading exactly works as grading can be very daunting to people who had not really written prior to Yale.

Strengths: I improved a lot in writing and understanding essays and language overall
Weaknesses: I heard that different teachers had different schemes (ex: some teachers allow students to skip an essay entirely)

Strengths: Professor Gellman was super invested in the course, the readings were fun and not too long, essay feedback was super useful.
Weaknesses: the discussion expectations were sometimes unclear. For example, it was sometimes unclear if we were supposed to raise our hands or just jump in. Beyond that, I think the discussions should have been less based on calling on people and more organic. However, I also recognize that the virtual format can make that difficult.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the virtual live lecture was helpful but being on unmute the entire time made me really nervous because there were always noises in the background.
I liked that Prof Gellman encouraged us to be unmuted so we could jump in the conversation.

I think the essay writing process (office hours, workshop, feedback) worked very well with the current system. Zoom discussions are just naturally difficult and awkward, but generally I think this class did a pretty good job of mitigating that. One thing I would suggest is that the first week or so of class muscle through the awkwardness and lack of productivity of an organic discussion instead of starting more structured and phasing out. It was hard for our class to let go of the structure and I think that made some of our discussions feel a little artificial. Another thing would be to do more breakout rooms, which made the discussion a lot less awkward and gave each student more opportunities to speak and listen closely.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would 100% recommend this course to another student, even if you're not confident about your writing. This class will teach you a lot and you'll be much more confident about attempting to write.

I would recommend this course, though maybe not to experienced writers. Though the regular essay assignments will help you to sharpen your skills regardless, the content of the class is a bit more basic that you might expect. Great for non-English majors and first-years of any major.
Yes!! It's interesting and challenging but also really fun to reflect on your own life and perspective and those of your classmates AND you work on important writing/communication skills.
Yes!! Awesome writing class with super interesting readings.

This has been my favorite course at Yale so far! I felt like my writing improved so much in regards to the ending. I do feel that grading really scared me in the course and in the end I did decide to credit D, but the readings and discussion were amazing!
yes!! i loved this class

Yes! I think every Yale student should take this course. Writing skills are essential to any profession and being able to persuasively and engagingly write about your thoughts/ideas/experiences is a very powerful tool. You also read some really fun essays by old and new authors. I definitely discovered some new authors that I really like and am going to read more of.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None
